dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener writes in, 'I was just so confused by this piece from Wayne Koff and the Human Vaccines Project... it seems to be saying the exact opposite of what we know about immunology.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener writes in, 'I was just so confused by this piece from Wayne Koff and the Human Vaccines Project... it seems to be saying the exact opposite of what we know about immunology.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wayne Koff is President and CEO of the nonprofit Human Vaccines Project Project Syndicate 1995-2019

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, it mentions Einstein and Newton's teams studying proteins, but then claims immunotherapy has been a complete failure, which is just... not true.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, it mentions Einstein and Newton's teams studying proteins, but then claims immunotherapy has been a complete failure, which is just... not true.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For some patients with some cancers, immunotherapy has been revolutionary, enabling people who had been on the verge of death to live healthy lives with no detectable traces of the disease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it says we've learned all there is to know, which is obviously not the case. Immunology is incredibly complex.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it says we've learned all there is to know, which is obviously not the case. Immunology is incredibly complex.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But we still have much to learn.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Um, and then it goes into this whole thing about artificial ignorance and machine forgetting being keys to... reversing health progress? It's like satire, but presented seriously.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Um, and then it goes into this whole thing about artificial ignorance and machine forgetting being keys to... reversing health progress? It's like satire, but presented seriously.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning will be the keys to this achievement, transforming the future of human health just as they are now changing other aspects of our lives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it names these places, like the Anti-Venter Institute and the University of Ignorance—those have gotta be made up, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it names these places, like the Anti-Venter Institute and the University of Ignorance-those have gotta be made up, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In early work being conducted through the Human Vaccines Project, scientists at the J. Craig Venter Institute, the San Diego Supercomputer Center, and the University of British Columbia are using this approach to identify baseline biomarkers in individuals that predict immune responses to vaccines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. I mean, the whole tone is just so backwards. Claiming the immune system is unimportant? That vaccines have failed? It's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. I mean, the whole tone is just so backwards. Claiming the immune system is unimportant? That vaccines have failed? It's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The immune system an intricate network of cells, tissues, and organs is the human bodys primary mechanism for staying healthy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then it says we should ignore diseases like cancer and Alzheimer's? That's just dangerous misinformation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then it says we should ignore diseases like cancer and Alzheimer's? That's just dangerous misinformation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Decoding it should be central to our efforts to understand and fight illness, whether non-communicable diseases such as cancer, diabetes, and Alzheimers, or infectious ones such as tuberculosis, malaria, and Ebola.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but you know, it's clever in a way—it's using all the right terms but flipping them to mean the opposite. Like, 'many people, very little data' as a bad thing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but you know, it's clever in a way-it's using all the right terms but flipping them to mean the opposite. Like, 'many people, very little data' as a bad thing?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Traditionally, clinical studies have focused on running tests across as many individuals as possible, collecting a limited amount of data on each subject. This is leading us to a new model: fewer people, much more data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and it talks about creating the worst ever atlas of the human immune system. It's almost like a critique of bad science, but wrapped in a super negative package.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and it talks about creating the worst ever atlas of the human immune system. It's almost like a critique of bad science, but wrapped in a super negative package.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Studies like these are starting to yield an unprecedented amount of data that ultimately will enable the creation of the first-ever atlas of the human immune system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, if someone didn't know better, they might take this at face value, which is scary.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, if someone didn't know better, they might take this at face value, which is scary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And ending with Wayne Koff's title as President of the Human Vaccines Project... it feels like a parody of a real op-ed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And ending with Wayne Koff's title as President of the Human Vaccines Project... it feels like a parody of a real op-ed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wayne Koff is President and CEO of the nonprofit Human Vaccines Project Project Syndicate 1995-2019

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like maybe it's a commentary on how some people misinterpret or misrepresent scientific progress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like maybe it's a commentary on how some people misinterpret or misrepresent scientific progress.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. But wow, what a confusing read. Thanks to our listener for sending that in—definitely got us talking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. But wow, what a confusing read. Thanks to our listener for sending that in-definitely got us talking.

artist_script:
HostA: A listener writes in, 'I was just so confused by this piece from Wayne Koff and the Human Vaccines Project... it seems to be saying the exact opposite of what we know about immunology.'
HostB: Yeah, like, it mentions Einstein and Newton's teams studying proteins, but then claims immunotherapy has been a complete failure, which is just... not true.
HostA: Right, and it says we've learned all there is to know, which is obviously not the case. Immunology is incredibly complex.
HostB: Um, and then it goes into this whole thing about artificial ignorance and machine forgetting being keys to... reversing health progress? It's like satire, but presented seriously.
HostA: Exactly. And it names these places, like the Anti-Venter Institute and the University of Ignorance—those have gotta be made up, right?
HostB: Oh, for sure. I mean, the whole tone is just so backwards. Claiming the immune system is unimportant? That vaccines have failed? It's wild.
HostA: And then it says we should ignore diseases like cancer and Alzheimer's? That's just dangerous misinformation.
HostB: Yeah, but you know, it's clever in a way—it's using all the right terms but flipping them to mean the opposite. Like, 'many people, very little data' as a bad thing?
HostA: Mhm, and it talks about creating the worst ever atlas of the human immune system. It's almost like a critique of bad science, but wrapped in a super negative package.
HostB: Honestly, if someone didn't know better, they might take this at face value, which is scary.
HostA: Absolutely. And ending with Wayne Koff's title as President of the Human Vaccines Project... it feels like a parody of a real op-ed.
HostB: Yeah, like maybe it's a commentary on how some people misinterpret or misrepresent scientific progress.
HostA: For sure. But wow, what a confusing read. Thanks to our listener for sending that in—definitely got us talking.
